name: Bagan
fun_fact: Fun fact: Bagan has over 2,000 ancient Buddhist temples and pagodas spread across 26 square miles - more than any other place on Earth. At its peak in the 11th-13th centuries, there were over 10,000 temples here!

hero_dishes.name: Mohinga
hero_dishes.description: Myanmar's national dish - rice noodle soup with fish-based broth, lemongrass, banana stem, and crispy fritters
hero_dishes.origin_story: The quintessential Burmese breakfast, typically eaten before 9am. Each region has its variation, but Bagan's is distinctly inland-style
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Morning street vendors, Sanon Training Restaurant, local tea shops

hero_dishes.name: Shan Noodles
hero_dishes.description: Rice noodles with tomato-based sauce, pickled vegetables, and chicken or pork
hero_dishes.origin_story: From the Shan State but beloved across Myanmar. Bagan serves it with local palm toddy vinegar
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Moon Vegetarian Restaurant, local noodle shops

hero_dishes.name: Burmese Curry
hero_dishes.description: Oil-rich curry with meat (often pork or chicken), tomatoes, and turmeric - served with rice and side dishes
hero_dishes.origin_story: The traditional one-plate meal of Myanmar - comes with soup, vegetables, and fermented tea leaf salad
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Moon Be Kind to Animals, Black Bamboo, local restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Htamin Jin
hero_dishes.description: Rice balls kneaded with turmeric-spiced oil, served with boiled egg and tamarind sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: A beloved snack often served at temples and festivals - portable and filling for pilgrims
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Tea shops, temple vendors, morning markets

signature_drinks.name: Toddy Palm Wine
signature_drinks.description: Fresh or fermented palm sap tapped from toddy palms - Bagan's specialty
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Fresh in the morning (sweet), fermented later (alcoholic) - watch toddy tappers climb palms at dawn

signature_drinks.name: Lahpet Yay
signature_drinks.description: Fermented tea leaf drink - Myanmar's unique tea tradition
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: In tea shops throughout the day - social lubricant of Burmese life

food_culture_notes: Tea shops are the social centers - endless refills of sweet tea are free
Lahpet (fermented tea leaf salad) is served at every significant occasion
Palm sugar from local toddy palms sweetens everything
Eating before temple visits is traditional - pack snacks for cycling
